title: Monday, 9th September 2019
bodyHTML:
VV75 morning
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Morning.

A. M. Morning all.
graunch Good morning
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:05am

And welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

JP11:06am

Morning all.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

And good to have you here, Jamie,

JP11:06am

Good to be back after a month or so of Bryce and I avoiding each other via holidays.

DRichi Getting closer to St Ledgers day, markets still quiet?
BE11:07am

Indeed. Though only two weeks of it involved avoiding the readers too, which is suboptimal.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Anyway, we have a Monday.

BE11:07am

There's the usual slew of Brexit stuff to get through, as well as some gold and oil if we're stuck.

JP11:08am

Yes please -- after two weeks away -- returning to catch up on UK politics is feeling a bit...

11:07 am
JP11:08am

Irish HF guy guten morgen all
BE11:08am

Yep, we'll do some "30% probability" stuff in a bit.

JP11:08am

(Not that I wasn't aware of what's going on, but distance cures the soul.)

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Corporate wise there's the Intu nonsense, Primark, Lloyds PPI, maybe some housebuilders on a frankly offensive HSBC note .....

GBKrona Hola
BE11:09am

Otherwise, open to requests.

undefined
Irish HF guy INTU properties up 10%+ today, Hammerson nearly £2.50!
cracklenpop Not being pedantic but I thought it was St. Leger's Day... or .maybe St. Ledger is the patron saint of auditors?
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Should we get the easy one out of the way first?

Peseta HFT Buenas dias
Intu Properties PLC (INTU:LSE): Last: 40.41, up 3.91 (+10.70%), High: 44.39, Low: 39.34, Volume: 5.93m
JP11:09am

Yes please.

mrlovepants Good morning all c:
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Soaring by about the same amount that it fell last week

BE11:10am

On a Sunday Times story:

BE11:10am

https://www.thetim...ant-intu-qdppf3zz3

mrlovepants Boris in Ireland today..
DRichi Cracklenpop- I believe the racing at Doncaster of the same name is on Saturday so presumed that Saturday was St Ledgers Day (14th)
Irish HF guy @cracklenpop, good one, St Matthew saint of accountants, bankers and bookkeepers
VV75 Astrazeneca looks weak today, although the headline seemed positive
11:11 am
JP11:11am

Here's a choice quote or two:

BE11:11am

Saying Orion -- deep underwater on its 9.2% or so of Intu, might buy the lot.

JP11:11am

Orion Capital Managers, run by Aref Lahham, is understood to be in the early stages of seeking partners for a buyout of Intu Properties, which has been battered by a string of insolvencies from retailers such as Debenhams and Sir Philip Green's Arcadia Group. Intu's rental income fell by almost 18% in the six months to June and the value of its portfolio, which also includes Lakeside in Essex, was slashed by 9.6%.

Intu's shares are trading at 36.5p, down by two-thirds since the start of the year and at an 85% discount to its net asset value. Orion first disclosed it was building a stake in January, when the shares were trading at 112p, meaning it is sitting on a significant paper loss.

Irish HF guy Intu, soaring is relative, 4p , but certainly indicative of potential value. I did say £0.30 was the floor as was £2 for Hammerson. Nice to see some value being recognised.
11:11 am
BE11:12am

So yeah, it's clearly a very well sourced story.

Soundbuy Orion was a hunter.........
BE11:12am

And Olly's a very good hack.

Icarus Hello
JP11:12am

Yep, he knows his beans.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

But ... .well, how do I put this politely? It can really only have come from one circle of sources, right?

BE11:13am

As in, people familiar with Orion Capital Managers.

Irish HF guy Whittaker needs take stake in PE bid to make back some of his mark to market losses on his Old Trafford Capital Shopping Centres stake which is now the mess called INTU
BE11:13am

Who have a quite large incentive to see the share price go up, owning as they do nearly 10% of the company.

11:13 am
JP11:13am

And being underwater on their investment...

BE11:14am

And who have a large incentive both to put pressure on Whittaker, the 27% holder by memory ... to put them in the boat when investigating a take private.

Irish HF guy Orion Capital Managers, L.P. have a Orion European Real Estate Fund V, which raised a €1.50 billion fund to invest precisely in these type of assets
Burt Morning BE - sorry to churn this up but the fcc agenda linked to on friday didn't mention ligado so slightly confused, wondering if you might be able to clarify, cheers
BE11:14am

Him plus Orion would leave £300m or so to cover at the current rate, which is very little.

A. M. (@irish: grüß gott)
11:14 am
BE11:15am

Though it's possible it could be littler still.

BE11:15am

(@Burt: it was a typo. There was no mention in the FCC docs. Sorry for the confusion.)

JP11:15am

Yep, we don't know the weighted average price paid do we?

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Just to remind on the zero outcome here, Stifel incoming.

Burt thanks
BE11:16am

We expect Intu's LTV will breach 60% over the next year, as valuations fall faster
than the company can reduce its debt burden. Our forecasts assume £500m of disposals
over the next 2.5 years. Against the backdrop of our assumptions for a falling portfolio
value, Intu would need to sell £1bn of assets (at book value) to keep the LTV below 60%,
and to reduce it to below 50% would require disposals totalling £2bn; given the almost
total lack of liquidity in the Retail property investment market, this seems fantastical to us.

JP11:16am

Omg smile

11:17 am
BE11:17am

What you're talking about now is one asset really, to carve out of Intu's burning shell.

BE11:17am

A point made by JP Morgan:

Irish HF guy INTU bid would need to be something north of £1 to £1.50 to make it acceptable at this level!
BE11:18am

Is there any value here? The tough underlying market and risk of equity issue means there is too much uncertainty for us to turn positive. However, it is hard to ignore that identifiable equity in Trafford is equal to 148% of the total market cap, inferring no value on the rest of the portfolio. (Fig. 1 & 2). Even at a 5.3% NIY (-15% revaluation) identifiable equity in Trafford equals 102% of the market cap. There is therefore ‘value’, and this does increase the risk of another approach in our view but with key milestones over the coming 18 months we think a wait & see approach will be taken.
 The timeline sees little reason to turn positive: In 2H19, we think Intu will likely announce the sale of at-least some Spanish assets (process has started at Asturias & Puerto Venezia) and legacy debt at Trafford will be refinanced. The terms will be interesting given Westfield’s recent raise at 1.642% for 7yrs. In 2020, a partial sale of Trafford is likely plus further disposals (we expect). Over this entire period though the underlying market is likely to be buffeted by further headwinds (CVAs, administrations, Brexit uncertainty) and portfolio values will continue falling.

cracklenpop @mrlovepantsI'd put good money (e.g long sterling) on an 'all-Ireland economic area' eventually being agreed. Basically, a re-badged 'border in the Irish Sea' that the EU originally proposed, but the UK government rejected cos of the DUP - who are now far less relevant in terms of the post-purge parliamentary arithmetic.
Irish HF guy Whittaker to take Trafford SC off INTU for £1.25bn
11:18 am
BE11:18am

JP11:19am

Which makes the trade still a bit of a difficult one, according to Peel Hunt:

JP11:19am

The Sunday Times reports that Orion Capital Managers (a private equity real estate investor) is in the early stages of exploring a buyout of Intu Properties. Orion has been building a stake over the course of this year and last disclosed a 9.2% holding. Given the recent share price weakness (down 68% YTD) they are currently sitting on a loss. Intu’s largest shareholder is John Whittaker’s Peel with 27.3%. Alongside The Olayan Group and Brookfield they attempted to take Intu private last year at 210p but Brookfield’s lenders reportedly got nervous. Any buyer would need a strategy and the resources to deal with Intu’s £4.9bn of net debt and in particular the significant maturities in 2021-23 which total over £2.5bn. Trading at an 85% discount to NAV and with no dividends being paid at present we believe the shares remain highly speculative. Any rumoured M&A activity is likely to have a positive read-across to Hammerson (Add TP 300p) where we continue to see the potential for further asset disposals to help a re-rating in the shares.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(@Irish: calm down or you're getting moderated. Don't make stuff up about M&A.)

JP11:19am

Highly speculative indeed.

BE11:19am

.... so anyway, to highlight the obvious, no statement out of Orion .....

Irish HF guy @BE, Okay, apologies.. those are my speculative thoughts only!
11:20 am
BE11:20am

... suggesting its thoughts that somehow were communicated to the Sunday Times are still no more than thoughts.

BE11:21am

With no contact made to Intu and no shareholders taken over the wall. So, it doesn't really move us on that much to be honest.

undefined
fortyeight Anybody who buys UK retail property at the moment needs their head examined. Empty rates is the same as being a perpetual tenant of HMG at about 50 per cent of an inflated rent.
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Okay, what next?

JP11:22am

Primark?

Markkus @cracklenpop - I agree, but the DUP and Unionism would be incandescent at this, to the point of civil insurrection.
JP11:22am

Sorry, Primani as it's also known as.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Aye, okay. Primark.

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,290, down 64 (-2.72%), High: 2,399, Low: 2,262, Volume: 295.39k
Are we there yet Also Intu is a really awful name
Irish HF guy @fortyeight, good point. Also key issue is the Rent costs to Sales percentage, something which NewRiver point out are much lower on their portfolio than say Hammerson (around 8% for NewRiver, 12% for UK portfolios of Intu and Hammerson)
BE11:23am

Still outperforming but in an increasingly challenging market.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Pre-close update confirmed that FY EPS will be flat as expected

JP11:23am

(@Are we there yet -- agreed, sounds like it should be a SAAS company offering HR software.)

fortyeight NewRiver are canny Scots.
BE11:24am

(It gets confused by people in a hurry with Intuit, which is inconvenient.)

cracklenpop @Markkus Insurrection would hardly be expressing the 'will of the people' as NI voted to stay in the EU.
11:24 am
BE11:24am

But year-on-years for Primark are looking a bit soft

BE11:24am

Here's Credit Suisse.

BE11:25am

Given soft comps, the 12 weeks of Primark 4Q were slightly disappointing in a soft UK market (est LFL -1%) but were better in Europe (est -1.4%) and FY LFL was -2% as expected. Elsewhere Grocery had a good year, helping offset the expected weakness in Sugar and Agri. For the year ahead we are cutting EBIT by 1.7%, due to the impact of adverse FX on Primark margins (-60bp vs -40bp, vs +44bp and +85bp in the prior two years), and are cutting EPS by 3.5% including due to higher financial charges (lower bond yields) and higher tax rates (22% vs 21%). This still gives 8% EPS growth, and 9% the following year, and forecasts exclude further restructuring in Bread, which is still materially loss making. We are trimming our 12m FWD target price from 2,750p to 2,650p accordingly.

Markkus The DUP don't care about that!
11:25 am
BE11:25am

With 64% of profits from overseas, ABF is broadly a beneficiary of sterling weakness, and in the event of a hard Brexit we would expect sugar profits to benefit from a tariff of €150/tonne, while Primark should benefit from the temporary halving of tariffs on apparel from China (47% of volumes). The shares trade on 15.7x 12m FWD PER (ex sugar) which we feel more than discounts softer recent trading at Primark and we estimate Primark is discounted at £8.8bn, or 12.5x PER, which is almost half that of H&M and Inditex, which have rallied 27% and 12% in the past 3 months.

JP11:25am

LFL of -2% is not..great.

BE11:26am

Uh, no, wait, H&M's rally is for H&M reasons. It says nothing of the market for £3 tee shirts.

cracklenpop @ Markkus Agree - they are after all the heirs of Carson.
11:26 am
JP11:26am

You have to wonder whether these fast fashion companies are going to be on the sharp end of anti-consumption politics over the next decade also.

JP11:26am

Anyway here's UBS:

JP11:26am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?A: FY outlook is unchanged, with adjusted EPS flat yoy. Divisional comments suggest a better performance than UBSe in Grocery and Sugar, with a weaker Primark Q4.Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?A: Primark FY sales increased by 4%, with -2% LFL. These are in line with the 40-week figures, suggesting no improvement against weaker Q4 comps. UK sales were +3% with -1% LFL. Europe was +5% and -3%, with Germany still a drag.Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?A: No group guidance yet for FY20, but Primark EBIT margin is expected to decline as a result of FX (UBSe +30bp). There may be scope to mitigate more as the year progresses.Q: How would we expect investors to react?A: Although the FX comments were unsurprising, a Primark margin decline and lack of Q4 recovery could see a subdued reaction today.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

.... and, yes, Primark's ability to squeeze more out of the floorspace has been on the wane for a while.

A. M. (re intu/intuit: MattL has a recurring section about people investing in the wrong company due to close ticker symbols. Could've been interesting)
Tsetse Anything on Abcam?
BE11:27am

Barclays too.

JP11:27am

I've not been to a Primark for a while, but remember thinking inventory was pretty stacked a few years back.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Primark still winning but in a slowing UK market:According to Kantar, the UK clothing market was down 2% YTDbut 4% in Q4. Primark was down only 1% in Q4,but still not as good as expected given generally helpfulweather. The continued outperformance is encouraging, but market weakness likely reflects lower consumer confidence around continued Brexit uncertainty. To put into context, we have seen poor trading from the likes of Debenhams, Top Shop and New Look. Continental European LFLs are improving (less than -2% LFL in Q4) despite the ongoing drag from Germany and the Netherlandswith France verystrong in Q4 (+6%), Iberia (+1-2%), and Italy excellent. US LFLs MSDin Q4

JP11:28am

Mike Ashley-style inventory display.

BE11:28am

Primark profit outlook remains strong: This is a good result given the weakness of sterling against its main buying currency of US dollars, helpedby a very low level of mark downs. H2 margins expected to declineby c.90bp(after a v strong H1)and management still expect margins to be lower in 2020 again mainly on FX headwinds. Some mitigation will come from lower cotton prices (down 20%) and theweakening Chinese RMB.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Rest of the portfolio: Trading in Sugarisencouragingand the inflection in 2020 sugar profits looks well set,helped by low inventories levels in the market.driving up EU sugar prices.Despite £16m of one offsin Grocery (Tea consolidation and Cardiff bakeryclosure) profits here would have been up DD. Ingredients and Agriculturetrading isless good. Ingredients have been hit by weakness in Argentina impacting AB Mauri

BE11:28am

Investment Case:ABF’s2019 profit outlook is unchanged. Its Brexit prep is complete and is a good hedge in the event of a hard Brexit. It has outlined its first indication on the IFRS 16impact(Net debt increased by £3.5bn, Primark margins up 90bp pro forma but net interest up). We continue to think ABF istrading well but in tough marketsa weakening £ is unhelpfulwhich drivesa 2% cut to our EPS forecasts in the out years. We still believe ABF is undervalued butwe trim our TP from 3400p to 3200p.

BE11:28am

Sorry for the run-together words there, but not sorry enough to fix them.

11:28 am
undefined
JP11:29am

Ha.

JP11:29am

To finish up -- Shore Capital Markets:

Pseudonym Wasn't it St Swithin's day anyway?
11:29 am
JP11:29am

In a weak UK market (low single digit negative) Primark has continued to make “significant” market share gains, with total sales up 3% including a LFL decline of 1%.
Eurozone sales are expected up +5% with strong sales highlighted in Spain, France, Italy and Belgium, with contribution from new stores in Bordeaux, Seville Torre and Ljubljana said to have “exceeded” expectations. LFL sales fell 3%, driven by the well documented challenges in Germany where it remains early days for the recently strengthened management/marketing teams.

US sales growth remains “strong” driven by the “excellent” Brooklyn store and broader LFL growth. US operating losses are expected to be “significantly” lower and we are encouraged by the broadening of new store growth into Florida and Chicago in the foreseeable future.

Irish HF guy @fortyeight, notwithstanding their share price has also suffered, they have make some very good investments in the pubs (Marstons) and retail parks at 8% 9% yields. Pimco also rate them (Bravo JV)
JP11:29am

Management is guiding to H2 2019 margin to be “lower” than the 11.7% in H1, though with the outlook for EBIT unchanged we reiterate our expectation for £905m, on a full year margin of 11.6% (so 11.4% through H2). Looking into FY2020 management is highlighting the currency headwinds from USD/GBP, whilst is part will be mitigated is expected to lead to “a reduced margin next year” when we has assumed flat.
FY2019 retail selling space increased by a gross 0.95 million sq ft, with management guiding to a net 1m sq ft in FY2019, which is a welcome increase and rates and ahead of our expectation, albeit H2 weighted, France and Spain will be the main beneficiaries, whilst the first store in Poland will opening the year. in Warsaw, taking Primark to its thirteenth country
Grocery sales ahead yoy, with adjusted EBIT “well ahead” despite the £12m headwind from closure costs in Twinings. Margin improvements are reported in George Weston Foods in Australia, ACH in the US, Twinings Ovaltine and Acetum. Twinings Ovaltine made good progress this year, with Twinings sales growth “strong” and Ovaltine sales growth driven by NPD in Switzerland. Allied Bakeries sales “progressed”, though the focus remains on reducing losses post contract losses that will impact FY2020.

JP11:29am

We leave our FY2019 forecasts unchanged, looking for EPS of 134.7p. However, given guidance on Primark margin, we anticipate pressure on our FY2020 expectations (currently 151.5p) and see the potential for 4-5% downward pressure. Trading a pre-downgrade FY2020 PER of 15.5x, EV/EBITDA multiple of

Sancho Anyone seen the new Volfefe index?
Sancho https://www.zerohedge.com/news/2019-09-08/jpmorgan-launches-volfefe-index-track-impact-volatility
11:31 am
JP11:31am

All done here?

BE11:31am

Yep. Such a pity that the Weston family control ABF as it kills the idea of an activist forcing a breakup.

Sancho interesting times
BE11:32am

Meaning we just have to waffle on about LFL and sales densities.

11:32 am
undefined
JP11:32am

That's the interesting stuff Bryce.

CrowK Primark in Lewisham definitely trying to go up market. I visit once a year so I notice
JP11:32am

Wink smile

cracklenpop "Sell in May and go away, and come back on St. Leger's Day."
11:32 am
BE11:32am

....... uh, okay. Otherwise in interesting stuff .....................

indexboy stobart buy out interest
BE11:33am

Request somewhere back there for Abcam.

JP11:33am

(@cracklenpop -- lol.)

tangledodyssey Stobart or ESL?
Pseudonym @cracklenpop Honestly, there's a St Swithins version...
11:34 am
BE11:34am

The suppliers of bits of rabbits to medical students.

JP11:34am

Never heard of Abcam.

Soundbuy Abcam -118000 antibodies- a shopper's paradise
tangledodyssey Never heard of Abcam?
BE11:35am

They do ... well, they do that. Rabbit monoclonal antibodies from a catalogue.

11:35 am
JP11:35am

Having just had a cursory look at their financials, seems like a good business.

Abcam PLC (ABC:LSE): Last: 1,130, down 110 (-8.87%), High: 1,229, Low: 1,089, Volume: 716.65k
BE11:36am

Investors are always very excited about them, whereas the scientists I have to talk to occasionally make noises about how they're the Primark of antibodies.

A. M. @BE: what does that mean, in the world of antibodies?
Soundbuy Fall apart after 2 washes?
11:36 am
BE11:37am

They'll sell you something but it might not be exactly what you want, and it might not do exactly what you think it will. That's my strictly anecdotal feedback.

A. M. sweatshop petri-dishes in some unsafe building?
DRichi Cracklenpop- St Leger not Ledger of course! D'oh. Edgg on my face
BE11:37am

Anyway, the strategic review is meh and the results are bad.

BE11:37am

Here's Panmure's Dr Julie Simmonds.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Abcam interim results slightly light on the bottom line, with higher than expected exceptionals. The five year plan indicates more of the same – increasing focus on higher value antibodies, continuing move into related areas and investment in the ‘customer experience’ all aiming to drive a higher growth rate. However, it comes at a significant cost, both near term impact on margins and a doubling of capital expenditure from already raised levels. We retain our sell recommendation.

BornCynic Christmas being mentioned already by some papers, along with more shrinkflation:https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/sep/09/happy-christmas-shrinkflation-trims-quality-street-again
BE11:38am

The outline of the five year plan is broadly similar to the current one, albeit with significant investment. The company aims to increase the antibody portfolio to target high value targets, pathways and research areas (broadly the current model) with a “step change” in targeted to improve the customer experience through e-commerce
and digital (presumably not coming through in the near term as customer engagement is expected to decline in 2019/20). Continued expansion of the portfolio in related areas e.g immunoassays and driving ‘Abcam Inside’ also targeted. Further investment in organisational scalability with replacement of legacy IT systems and simplification of global footprint.

A. M. @BornCynic: it's not even October.. (sigh)
BE11:39am

T he previous five year plan promised a doubling of revenue, the introduction of an ERP system and move to a new building. Each of these was achieved, albeit with more investment than was originally envisaged. The latter two processes were expected to raise margins following the completion of these products, however, the program of investments laid out this morning indicates that margins will decline in the near term to generate the growth. New KPI’ s are catalogue growth from in -house products of 12-15% (compared to 9.8% FY 2019) and customer engagement of 54-60% (lower than that targeted in 2019 57-67%, where 59% was achieved.

Soundbuy Christmas? Jeez...........guessing for those folk who you find it difficult to buy for, an Abcam catalogue may be of some use.......
11:39 am
BE11:40am

Abcam has underperformed since July and is currently trading at 20% above its five year premium to the sector. It continues to trade at market high multiples, currently 25.2x EBITDA and 32.4x PE FY 2020 and in our view remains over valued compared to its peer group, particularly since we expect further pressure on consensus from investment in the new strategy.

JP11:40am

25.2x EBITDA -- yeesh.

BE11:40am

And Stifel, also grumbling about jam tomorrow.

A. M. @Soundbuy: well, I remember seeing some virus/bactreria plush animals, for the microbiology-inclined.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Abcam has announced its FY19 results in line with expectations, with revenues up 9.2% at CER
(11.4% reported), to £259.9m as previously reported in its full-year trading statement. Weakness in
Japan and a decline in the custom project side of Abcam Inside were the reason for the slowing
growth rate, that missed the revised guidance of 10%. The company delivered fractionally better adj.
EBITDA margin than guided (35%), delivering 35.6%, which drove adj. EPS to marginally beat our
forecasts at 32.6p (Stifel est 32.0p, consensus 32.2p). Abcam has also announced a new five-year
investment plan targeting revenues of £450-500m in FY24, an implied CAGR of between 11.6% and
14.0% with an adj. EBIT margin of 30%+ (FY19A: 32.2%). Guidance for FY20 is for 9-11% revenue
growth and adj. EBIT margins of 25-28%. The acceleration in top-line growth is expected to be driven
by further strategic operational and capital investments. With margins expected to decline in the
next few years before recovering over five years, we believe that the jam is thoroughly in the future.
We reduce our estimates by between 8-10% between FY20-22 (summary overleaf) and therefore
reduce our target price by 10% to 1,000p (from 1,100p) in line with our DCF and peer comparison
analysis. We therefore downgrade our recommendation to Sell from Hold.

Blakemorio 25.2x EBITDA...
BE11:41am

Over the past 18 months, Abcam has narrowly but consistently missed its
revenue growth guidance, with each announcement negatively impacting the share price. With the
announcement of the details of its five-year plan, the near-term margin impact is far higher than we
expected, putting the potential benefits of the plan firmly in to the future. We see fair value at 1,000p
on our DCF and peer comparison, we therefore downgrade our rating to Sell.

NFC 2kg tin at Costco appeals to me (I will be getting very fat)
Soundbuy @A.M - lovely.........
BE11:41am

Hope that's the kind of thing you were after, commenter.

Montesquieu Given the increasingly dynamic nature of competitor ecosystems and operating models, I do sometimes marvel at the continued fashion for five year plans. Direction of travel at best, replete with hostages to fortune.
A. M. (Speaking of which, how about a crematorium lego-set? Complete with coffin)
cracklenpop @DRichi - no worries, any thoughts on the race itself? Saw Sir Dragonet trot up at Chester, looks a likely Leger sort....
Tsetse It was indeed, thank you BE
11:41 am
JP11:42am

Here's Peel Hunt to finish:

JP11:42am

FY19 financial headlines as expected but impairment added today – The trading updateon 22 July provided the top-line growth of 9.2% CER (11.4% reported), and comfort on EBITDA margins was confirmed today at 35.6% for FY19, a slight beat to a bearish consensus (34.6% vs PHe 35.6%). Adjusted operating profit (£83.6m), PBT (£83.9) and EPS (32.6p) were all marginally ahead (c1-2%) of our numbers too but reported numbers were significantly impacted by a £12.8m non-cash impairment charge for historical costs from the Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) implementation.

JP11:42am

The new five-year growth plan is ‘removing constraints to growth’ – Management has often talked to us about the breadth of opportunities open to the company and ‘getting out from under their own feet’ to execute on them all. Today, ambitious guidance to grow revenues at CAGR c11-14% out to FY24 (c£450m-500m vs PHe of £420m prior to today’s update) represents the company now committing to do this. Management has described to us two key areas where it will focus (in addition to Abcam’s world-class research antibody tools and the Abcam Inside/CP&L portfolio) and we therefore add this revenue into ‘Other products’ & ‘Recombinants’

11:42 am
JP11:42am

This new top-line growth does come at a cost – Our assumptions (we will review with management in due course) for the strategic, operational and capital investments to remove constraints to growth (changes to forecasts in table 5) include: Capex, which is guided to be c£175-225m over the period to FY24 (PH now include £200m vs £125m previously). Building facilities in automation and manufacturing were mentioned to us alongside IT platforms (for both ecommerce and warehouse management). Management guides for c£30-50m investment in FY20 (PHe c£35m). SG&A – management has described the need to invest in ‘customer experience’ to ensure it stays ahead of the competition but we would also expect some costs for marketing/sales teams to support the growth in other product areas. Revised PHe for FY20E/21E/22E SG&A are c£78m/£85m/£93m (vs c£89 in FY19 including c£12.8m impairment). This is an increase of c14%/12%11%, respectively, vs prior estimates. R&D – we marginally increase (c4% p.a.) spend here too to account for the necessary R&D costs to support additional focus on protein and gene-editing products, giving c£26m£30m/£34m for FY20E/21E/22E.

Shinshin Parliament recess starting today apparently

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Recent machinations in Westminster point to no short-term fix to Brexit paralysis, albeit a nearterm
no deal Brexit appears to be ruled out, unless a snap election achieves a mandate for that.
See HSBC Economics’ note, Yes to Benn bill, no (for now) to an election, 4 September 2019.
In any case, we believe the downside political and economic risks of investing in housebuilders
are more than priced in for the ten housebuilders stocks under our coverage, following the pullback
by an average 10% since the recent peak in early March 2019. Share prices are now
nearly 13% lower on average than 18 June 2018, when evidence of a decline in the
discretionary strata of the southern England housing market first became apparent and before
Brexit uncertainty caused a Q4 2018 slump in the sector and broader UK index.
We see the range of housing market outturns to economic and political scenarios as follows:
 Our base case for a 2.5-5% fall in southern England new home prices in H2 2019/H1 2020e
(flat in other regions) is consistent in our opinion, with the status quo of continued political
paralysis and a stagnant economy, with an average 42% upside implied by our target prices
 Our bear scenario for a 7.5-10% fall in southern England new home prices in H2 2019/H1
2020e (flat in other regions) is consistent in our opinion with an early 1990s style recession
that could be caused by a no deal Brexit and projects an average 19% share price upside
to our bear scenario valuations.
 Our bull scenario for continued flat southern England new home prices in H2 2019/H1
2020e (+2% in other regions) is similar to consensus and could be sustained if the current
economic stagnation continues, or improves, and projects an average 72% share price
upside to our bull scenario valuations.

BE11:54am

UK housebuilders are the second highest dividend yielding subsector in the FTSE 350 (after
tobacco) at an average FY2019e 8.6% and four are in the FTSE 350 top-20 prospective dividend
yielding stocks at an average 11% in FY 2019e, rising to 11.5% by FY 2022e on our estimates.
These high dividend yields are sustained in each of our base, bear and bull cases as a result of
the following:
 The balance of power in the housing land market has shifted from landowners to the larger
housebuilders, with planning reform substantially increasing the supply of permitted housing
land. Meanwhile, housebuilders’ competition has decreased due to scale advantages,
industry consolidation in the last 30 years and the demise of SME competition in a more
risk-averse bank lending climate.
 Low mortgage costs are likely to continue, supporting the recent shift to new home
ownership from renting that is boosting housebuilders’ sales rates despite the depressed
wider housing market.
 Despite our base case expectation of new home price falls in southern England, and more
significant reductions in our bear scenario reducing EBIT outturns, free cash flow in 2019-20e
rises from 2018 levels through lower required stocks of land and replacement at lower prices.

BE12:02pm

So far, unlike ineffective Ryanair strikes, IAG's BA has been fully
impacted by BALPA action. We see likely collateral damage on non-strike
days from displaced lower fare passengers being rebooked into seats
that otherwise might have been sold later at a higher price. We also
think that (like at AFKLM and SAS in the last year) forward bookings will
also temporarily weaken as the dispute persists - but bounce back once
the dispute is settled.
• Today's indication of worsening pricing from AFKLM will also not help
IAG shares - with BA most exposed to UK Brexit issues. We cut IAG EBIT
projections a further 3% today.
• Balpa threatens more strike dates through to January 2020. At Ryanair,
Balpa have already added strike dates (albeit to ineffective action,
so far). The Times, 7/9/19 reports Balpa confirming more strikes are
possible at BA (beyond that already planned for 27/09/19). In contrast
to Ryanair, the high 93% level of support from Balpa pilots at BA to
strike, and reports of union/group financial support for lesser paid pilots
suggest a union digging-in for a long dispute.
• So what? We estimated a dispute might cost IAG €50m/day of lost
profits but this increases non linearly the longer a dispute drags on.
• For IAG's BA, the balance is to ensure it remains cost competitive.
Here, Wizz Air has already displaced BA off London-Bergen, Kiev and St
Petersburg. However, the longer the BA dispute runs, the greater the
risk that short-term (and temporary) profit cost rises and cannot offset
long-term cost inflation avoided.
• IAG shares presently price-in a greater than 20% EBIT downgrade -
provided the multiple recovers. However, trading at an AFKLM EV/
EBITDA of 3.5x the push-back we now get is that tech-glitch-led and
Union disruption at BA has left IAG's main profit driver behaving like
AFKLM of past years, i.e. grounded several days a year. IAG's group-wide
RoCE has been higher, but a growing risk is that the more BA is grounded
from tech and strikes, the more a low multiple perception sticks.

It may not feel like it, but the structural underpinnings of the European airline sector continue to improve. Those that deliver, i.e. the five leading airlines, now control over 60% of intra-European capacity and almost 90% of profits. The ‘rest’, exceptfor Wizz, are characterised by a long tail and are struggling. Wethink industry consolidation is likely to continue and argue thateven easyJet could be a target over the medium term. Meanwhile,valuations have collapsed, with Ryanair trading near the bottom ofits range against fleet value and IAG less than 4x P/E. Both are structuralwinners.

As part of [Easyjet's] focus on driving profit per seat and cash flow, easyJet plans to grow capacity at the lower end of its historic growth rates in financial year 2020, particularly in winter, which includes expected fleet growth to reach 332 aircraft by the end of financial year 2019, 349 aircraft by the end of financial year 2020 and 352 aircraft by the end of financial year 2021. We think weak sterling, stubborn competitor capacity and a tough prior-year fuel comparable will constrain profit growth in 2020. Sterling has previously (notably in the 2015-2017 period) inhibited PBT growth. Ultimately, a lack of strategic opportunity (making recent expansion at Berlin, Manchester and easyJet Holidays summer 2020 launch important) constrains the multiple and could make easyJet a take-over target.
